Very small outside chance that the House will do this.  However, the Kochs are against it, so nobody who votes for it will win a Republican primary ever again, perhaps including poor little Paul Ryan.  I remain a Republican solely for the entertainment value these days.
There is not enough time for anything like this to happen.  Most are too focused on Gorsuch or repealing Obamacare to focus on this.

At risk of being caught out (again) in the Post-Rational new world order this looks like a very complicated tax that it is unclear how effective it would be, unclear if it would be legal under WTO rules, and would appear to make the US tax system even more complicated than it is now. Surely it would be better to come up with a general overhaul of the US tax system. simplify it all and introduce a Value Added Tax system that would (a) be legal under WTO rules (b) rational and simple (c) do what Trump and other want a border adjustment tax to do. What's not to like with VAT?  All OECD countries except the USA have VAT systems, 160 out of 193 countries of the world use it. The only problem I see is Not Invented Here, and maybe even worse it was invented in Europe.  
I am assuming the border adjustment tax (perhaps wrongly) that it will not be passed in the next 27 days.

Not enough clarity from US Gvt to think this will be announced before q deadline. Lobby groups working hard for and against. Lobbying for favour is not something I think trump would rush as the relationships benefit his business...once he's out of office of course :-p
Because all indications are that tax policy debates will last into the summer.
Too many other items on the front burner.  Not something that needs to be addressed soon
way too complicated with a lot of foes
Tax reform is highly unlikely to go through within the next month. The Senate is gearing up for a supreme court battle. There won't be time or attention for a border adjustment tax.

2.5 legislative weeks remain. GOP suffered a major setback with AHCA. WH is pushing tax reform as the next major piece of legislation. Congress still needs to pass FY17 Approps or CR prior to 28 April. There has been no significant move to develop this legislation.
It either will or it won't by the senate or the house. 1:4.
In my understanding there isn't even anything close to a official proposal yet, just talks and discussions, so its way too early to get this done

Trump's popularity cache has waned. Moderate Conservatives have shown less willingness to be publicly tied to the Trump to the president due to the potential midterm election fallout from the Russian investigation and unpopular health plan bill. Gallop polls show that is the most unpopular president ever this early into his term. There will be little enthusiasm for a BAT plan and even if passed, certainly won't happen before 4/30. https://www.wsj.com/articles/fbi-probe-could-hurt-donald-trumps-clout-in-congress-1490053226

AHCA is the primary concern for House and Senate Republicans, followed by comprehensive tax reform. Only 4 weeks in session remain, and Senate has Gorsuch hearing and any other cabinet hearings they decide to schedule. HPSCI and SSCI are tied up with Russia investigation hearings. Neither House nor Senate have discussed adding this to the legislative agenda. Trump is not overly supportive of such legislation, and pursuing this in the next month distracts from other GOP efforts in a negative way.

It seems health care reform is currently the main agenda of the Republican party[1], which means tax reform is a lower priority. Crowded legislative calendar[2] means passage by April 30 is unlikely. President Donald Trump may begin his overhaul of the U.S. tax code as early as late spring, White House spokesman Sean Spicer has told Ireland's Sunday Independent newspaper. "We are going to have tax reform after we get healthcare completed... I think we are looking at late spring to summer," Spicer told the newspaper in an interview during Irish Prime Minister Enda Kenny's visit to Washington late last week.

However, based on the question, Either the Senate OR the House would need to pass this in the next ~45 days. The House seems to have support for it, even though the Senate doesn't. That's enough to satisfy the question, isn't it?

Dropping 20 points, should have been updating this prediction more regularly. Anyway, I'll be generous and say it seems congress is going to keep focusing on healthcare and a border adjustment tax is definitely a second tier issue for them; probably has nothing to do with general congressional dysfunction.

http://www.afr.com/news/politics/world/donald-trump-signals-timing-of-border-tax-20170228-gumz7e#ixzz4ayfSF9wX  Feb 28, 2017 " . . . the tax overhaul will be delayed until a divided Congress agrees on the "complicated" task of replacing former president Barack Obama's health insurance law, Mr Trump said.
. . . 
"The President is unlikely to have the final say on tax reform, with both the House and Senate heavily involved in negotiations and pushing competing agendas. The House leadership favours a 20 per cent BAT which would tax domestic sales, exempt exports and deny deductibility for imports. House speaker Paul Ryan - backed by economists - argues the policy would be pro-economic growth and not protectionist because the US dollar would rise up to 25 per cent due to the tax's impact on trade and capital flows. However, several Republican senators oppose any import tax because of concerns it could raise consumer prices or ignite an international trade war between countries. . . . Fiscally-conservative Republicans in Congress insisting on revenue neutral tax reform are worried Mr Trump will dodge slashing the government's $US19 trillion gross debt and may even add to it.
. . . 
"The "skinny" budget due in March will not be a complete fiscal document and be bereft of tax reform revenue projections, the President's budget director Mick Mulvaney said. The tax details are expected to be contained in a separate publication after the mini-budget, once the Congress agrees how to fix the divisive Obamacare health insurance law. "For budget purposes we have to do healthcare before we do a tax cut," Mr Trump said, "because we have to know what the healthcare is going to cost". Read more: http://www.afr.com/news/politics/world/donald-trump-signals-timing-of-border-tax-20170228-gumz7e#ixzz4ayfSF9wX

EDIT: I didn't realize I assigned an original 18% probability ~3 weeks ago.  My current 41% chance forecast is my most recent, and an increase from the initial forecast of 18%. I think there may be some movement to take away the focus from the current issues.  That may speed up this legislation. There are clearly two different camps of thought on this issue (cited below).  I'm not sure (hence my 39% probability forecast)  for two reasons: (1) April 30, 2017 is 7 weeks away. There's a lot going on in Washington, albeit it could be fast-tracked. (2) According to some economists, the dollar's value has to increase 20% for the border tax to work according to some.  That may diminish it's chances.  Some of forecasting an impact on consumers. I don't think it will be likely but not ruling it out. The dollar's value and some economics of the border tax are discussed here:

- Only 60 days left
- There is a strong lobbying effort against it that will gather further momentum
- Both Donald Trump and Gary Kohn have waffled on it
- Steve Mnuchin expects tax reform in Aug
- He is prioritizing immigration and Obamacare 20% chance because Trump may have in his mind a desire to do something on the economy in the first 100 days and this would likely get him positive press  to change the news cycle (e.g. Supreme Court nominee)

I am flip flopping a lot on this one. One day Trump appears to be against it, the next not so much. Even if it happens will it occur before April 30th or will there be a longer negotiation. The border adjustment tax may be the only way to pay for everything Trump has promised. I am upgrading this significantly today and I am ready to continue moving it up as needed. The Trump administration is now dealing with the most volatile issues (health care, trade, taxes) where the repercussions for your action can impact Trump and every Republican congressman and even state governors and state legislators. Unlike the wall and immigration crackdowns, issues like health care, trade and taxes have the potential to split the Republicans base. Any forecaster who gets all of these types of questions right would be very impressive.

Not enough time to carefully impose such of a tax.  I expect the threat of the tax to remain while negotiations with Mexico and Corporate CEOs continue.

The DealMaker has spoken Trump Signals Support for Border-Adjustment Tax 
https://www.usnews.com/news/articles/2017-02-24/trump-signals-support-for-border-adjustment-tax-plan-pushed-by-house-republicans Exclusive: Trump says Republican border tax could boost U.S. jobs
http://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-trump-tax-exclusive-idUSKBN1622J5

Despite it being "too complicated," Trump himself, in his own Trumpian way, seems to be coming around to it:
“It could lead to a lot more jobs in the United States. ... I certainly support a form of tax on the border because everybody else does. We’re the only country, we’re one of the very few countries, possibly the only country, that has no border tax. And that’s not a tax to the consumer, because that’s going to be a tax to companies and it’s going to be a tax to other countries much more so than it is to the consumer. That’s a tax to other countries. And what will happen is, don’t forget there is no tax if we make our product in the United States. So I don’t consider it a tax. That’s a tax if companies are buying their product outside of the United States. But ... if they make their product in the United States, there is no tax. So what is going to happen is companies are going to come back here, they’re going to build their factories and they’re going to create a lot of jobs and there’s no tax.”
http://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-trump-interview-highlights-idUSKBN1622RG Trump may not fully understand it, but he does, somehow, reach the same conclusion promoted by knowledgeable proponents. It's ridiculous that the United States has not leveraged its large and lucrative domestic market for its own benefit. There is meaning in semantics, and It might help, a bit at least, if people considered themselves to be "purchasers" within an integrated system, recognizing their inherent purchasing *power*, rather than isolated and dis-empowered "consumers." Despite its origin within the GOP, this is really a true populist item, designed to benefit the common good, the entire commonwealth. Clear sighted Democrats should be supporting this, but it is possible that they won't be able to see beyond their resistance to Trump to embrace this item of empowered democracy. In addition to the immediate economic benefits, I would personally welcome the increased manufacturing innovation and increased product variety that might reasonably be anticipated to be spurred by such an approach. My forecast remains low primarily due to timing. Edit/Update1: Here is the most succinct correct statement that I have seen so far of exactly what (at least one version) of the border adjustment tax actually is: "The so-called border adjustment tax would revamp the corporate tax code, preventing companies from deducting the cost of imports from their taxable incomes"
https://www.buzzfeed.com/matthewzeitlin/companies-adding-trump-related-risk-factors?utm_term=.qtYEyOm4q#.bmE3n90JP In regard to the Buzzfeed article, corporations are well advised to make these disclosures of political risks. As an aside, can you imagine the nightmare which would have likely ensued under the "investor protection" clauses if the United States were bound to some of the macro regional trade agreements (e.g, TTIP and TPP)? In a speech today Trump vowed to make the GOP "the party of the American worker," which is simply an astounding aspiration. These free trade deals have been the result of an alliance between the "establishment" of both political parties. American workers were sold out for special corporate interests, with the entire society suffering the deleterious effects (Ross Perot was right), covered by the sop of lower prices. That the Democratic party leadership betrayed their base constituency (domestic labor) and threw them under the bus to obtain benefit from a corporate clique, and are now being challenged by Trump over this key historical constituency is just simply amazing. I don't like Trump, consider him to be no more than a front for Russian-dominated organized crime, but on this one issue -- a populist approach to political economics -- he's correct (imo). I do worry that he's the wrong messenger for such an important message, which makes getting to the point where such a populist political economic program would demonstrate its merit very precarious; or that the good may suffer from association with the bad; or that Trump is being used, as he so often (willingly and knowingly) has been, to somehow set it up for failure; or that he will find some Trumpian way to perhaps go too far and screw it up. One more bit of assurance to those who may be reluctant to embrace this conception: the business does not go away! It is simply redistributed. Edit/Update2: Gary Cohn, chief economic advisor to President Trump, says "no go" on border adjustment tax
https://www.axios.com/trump-econ-advisor-no-go-on-house-border-adjustment-tax-2282642439.html It is not surprising that Cohn, ex-President of Goldman Sachs, has come out against the border adjustment tax. If we understand corruption to be the selling out of "the many" by betrayal of some duty of protection inherent in some organizational role (whether fiduciary or in some weaker form of organizational trust) for the benefit of "the few," we see that much of the Goldman Sachs business model is to act as corruptor to various "insiders" (the would-be corruptees) [think of the Greek debt, a private "deal" affecting public resources; or, as is common in insider-trading and bankruptcies, such as Trump's initial Manhattan Conrail property acquisition, where he was, I believe, the channel to siphon the benefit of the corruption]. By eliminating a systemic vulnerability, a border adjustment tax would radically change a condition of the system which Goldman Sachs relies upon for their approach. It would be much harder for them to extract profits from a broader set of diffused transactions (with the vulnerability [risk] of exploitation [via corruption] similarly diffused), among other things. Yet, there remains some glimmer of hope in that the White House has not, so far, come out in direct opposition to the House GOP plan. As is becoming expected with the Trump administration, there appears to be two opposing camps on "border adjustment" generally. For the sake of clarity, in future forecasts I will use the term "border adjustment tax" to mean the stronger, more populist (the equal protection of everyone's interests) House GOP plan (or at least that version of which I am familiar), and adopt the term "border adjustability tax" to refer to the weaker, less populist (allowing special interests to prevail) plan which the likes of Cohn et. al. might come up with. Obviously, since the latter term is adopted from the language of the White House, you can see that I am not optimistic that the stronger, better, plan will succeed. --
"In many cases, the entities involved have more resources than the countries they target and exploit."
https://www.forbes.com/sites/realspin/2017/02/23/us-uk-must-target-law-firms-facilitating-african-corruption/#f008eba12289 In a better world, the U.S. would be leading such an initiative, rather than letting struggling nations such as the Republic of Guinea flounder amongst the sharks. Unfortunately, the U.S. itself is crippled by corruption (albeit its secretive nature preventing most from recognizing its full extent). The smartest thing anyone could do would be to turn the vast intelligence and enforcement resources created to fight the (manufactured) phenomenon of "terrorism" against all levels of political corruption.
If it isn't on Trump's radar it likely won't happen.

I am starting at 25% because I think the house has a chance to pass a border adjustment tax but with so many other things going on there is a good chance they simply don't get around to it in the next two months.

slightly upgrading since a) meeting at white house, Trump can establish by executive order http://money.cnn.com/2017/01/23/news/economy/trump-tariff-power/ and c) only EITHER house or senate has to approve for "yes" answer.

There is a conflation of the notions of "good for business" and "good for the populace" that is ongoing within the administration and among the pundits. Reportedly numerous representatives of large retailers and manufacturers within certain segments are strongly opposed to a border adjustment tax, and this opposition is being used to discredit the tax as a potential benefit to the overall economy and the populace generally (via increased domestic investment and increased demand for domestic production by domestic workers). So long as the idea that "What's good for General Motors (or Walmart, or whomever) is good for America" remains unchallenged, the border adjustment tax will remain "too complicated" and too easily dismissed.

At the outset of Trump's term, Republican lawmakers, lobbyists and tax experts were planning to repeal Obamacare in February, then begin revamping the tax code in March. Now, House Republicans say they may pass a tax-reform bill by August. That would force the Senate to take up the issue at the start of the 2018 midterm election season, a bad time for lawmakers to be making hard decisions.

A border adjustment tax would have to be part of a both a larger tax overhaul (Ryan's job) and a change in foreign trade policy (Tillerson's job). That's a lot of moving parts. Left to do their jobs, I think those two could pull it off, but not in such a short time frame. (Besides which, they won't be allowed to do their jobs.)

I have been reading this Q carelessly--it only calls for one of the two chambers to pass a bill.  The House probably will.  They say so, anyway, for whatever that's worth. Border adjustment tax will be part of tax reform, chief GOP tax writer says The Republican's chief tax writer, Rep. Kevin Brady, told CNBC on Wednesday he is "confident" that the border adjustment tax will be included in the tax reform plan, despite some opposition to the controversial measure. That's because it is a "critical" component of the plan, the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee said in an interview with "Closing Bell."

As mentioned by others, timeline is too aggressive.  If the GOP is likely to go to war with Trump, it is very unlikely to be on something like a tariff, where Trump is the one breaking the GOP norm, and it won't be in anything that can be called raising a tax.  If they did pass something he didn't want, it would be a stronger ideological litmus bill, like gun rights or abortion.  In any case, the Senate is unlikely to touch any of this in any circumstance.

I believe it will eventually be passed, but then not become law. However, April 30, 2017 is extremely aggressive for a bill that essentially splits American corporations. If this was going to pass, we would have seen more debate about it prior to now, as well as a few iterations of the draft bill. They are too far behind the curveball to pass a bill that will split corporations.

https://www.benzinga.com/analyst-ratings/analyst-color/17/02/9037053/analyst-sees-odds-of-u-s-border-tax-passage-increasing-t "Height Securities has increased the odds of Border Tax Adjustment (BTA) passage to 75 percent from 60 percent previously. “[W]e believe there will ultimately be at least 21 votes in the Ways and Means Committee in favor of border adjustment among the committee’s 39 members (23 of whom are Republican). If the committee meets that threshold, we expect there will be more than the required 218 votes in favor on the House floor,” analyst Henrietta Treyz wrote in a note. "The analyst said odds remain 30 percent that this bill can pass the U.S. Senate. "Treyz, who believes the potential BTA bill must pass the House by August, says if it is delayed until October, “the view right now is that it will wither on the vine.”
“We would look to the May/June timeframe as the most likely at this time,” Treyz continued. "That said, there is still time for the BTA idea to gain traction as lobbying is going on aggressively despite many [more] corporations are opposing the BTA than supporting it at present.
. . . 
". . . Treyz expects the White House to release its “phenomenal tax plan” in tandem with Trump’s February 28 speech to a joint session of Congress.

"I think the probability of a border tax is very low."  He said the appointment of former ExxonMobil CEO Rex Tillerson as U.S. secretary of state is encouraging as he is familiar with the oilsands industry and recognizes that Canadian oil and gas is vital to the American economy. "Williams' view runs counter to some who worry about the damage a border adjustment tax could inflict upon Canada's energy industry. TD Securities energy analyst Menno Hulshof said in a report Thursday he estimates Canadian oil and gas producers have lost about $10 billion in stock value because of investors' border tax concerns that began to take hold in mid-December. "On the call, Williams said he doesn't think any energy companies — Suncor or its rivals — will invest in oil sands mining for "in excess of 10 years" due to high costs and low oil prices.

Senator David Perdue (R-GA) comes out in opposition to the border adjustment tax.
http://www.cnbc.com/2017/02/09/border-adjusted-tax-runs-into-trouble-in-the-senate.html But of course. Perdue "previously served as the CEO of Dollar General, a company that imports heavily." A Senator is, nominally, charged with representing the interests of his/her entire state, as well as keeping an eye on the interests of the entire country. Instead, Perdue adopts the parochial perspective of a retailer that has built its business model around imports from China. One of my first posts on GJO was about how I was surprised that so-called "Dollar Stores" carried plastic drinking straws imported from China. Together with a few other forecasters we explored the economics of this. Contrary to the arguments of Perdue, the border adjustment tax would incentivize firms to have those straws made in America, which will add (or rather return) displaced jobs, increasing the overall economy, and allowing the greater volume of transactions to help everybody (as those workers spend their wages, and that spending is spent, and so on). Stores such as Dollar General are in a sweet spot, having optimized supply chains that reach into Communist party controlled factories in China. That they do not wish to give up the gravy train is understandable. But that Perdue, a U.S. Senator, should sell out his constituents in Georgia, and the citizens of the United States, is unforgivable. Stores such as Dollar General can adjust, but they'd rather maintain an inverted tax system to keep their near-monopoly via the Communist Chinese leadership. They are fat and lazy. "If you go to a system like this, you're going to get massive economic growth"
http://www.weeklystandard.com/too-complicated/article/2006775#! I agree. MASSIVE is right. If people would just invest some time in understanding it, they'd see for themselves. Even CNBC, a cable network with roots as a financial news service, mistakenly (misleadingly?) describes the border adjustment tax as a "proposal [which] would put a 20 percent tax on imports." But just because it is slightly more complicated, it's not that difficult to understand at all. More American workers. More investment in Plant & Equipment. More transactions, across-the-board. All businesses, as well as the workers, do better. In addition, and this point is often overlooked, there will be more diversity in all product offerings. Instead of the single Chinese source optimized to make "basic" product X with only the most basic standard features for the product category, you will have all sorts of variety and choice. I am not optimistic such a "tax" will be passed within the timeframe. I am also skeptical that the current crop of politicians won't find ways to pervert it in such a way so as to turn a really good thing into, as Trump says. a "disaster."
A border adjustment tax might be part of a larger corporate and individual tax package passed later in 2017.

The following article does a decent job of describing the border adjustment tax. It's easy to see how this tax may be perceived as being, as Trump says, "complicated," and may require a large percentage of American voters to rely upon the expertise of others so as to interpret its significance and impact. http://nymag.com/daily/intelligencer/2017/02/the-gops-corporate-tax-plan-would-raise-taxes-on-the-poor.html Yet, despite the decent treatment of this adjustment tax by the author, he ends up with an unwarranted conclusion (i.e. "redistributing wealth upward"). The key to understanding this tax is to recognize that most Americans are both producers and consumers. By incentivizing American sourcing, thus increasing the demand for American production and workers, there will be more money (greater velocity of transactions) within the domestic economy which will, in general, increase the demand for *all* goods and services. The slightly more expensive tee-shirt at Walmart would be offset for that Walmart consumer by (first, having a job! and second, by) a wage increase (as a producer), and more than offset for that very same consumer by lower direct taxes to support non-productive workers in the economy. It will also drive major investment in plant and technology within the United States. It really is a better approach to corporate taxation than the model the U.S. currently uses, and would reverse the position of the U.S. getting "ripped off" (as Trump rightfully laments) by leveraging the size of the domestic market for the benefit of all citizens. On this one point Trump is exactly correct. The rest of the G7, in private, must really think the U.S. is a bunch of fools for having current tax and trade policies that are so disadvantageous to U.S. citizens. It's the only tax approach that prevents a (potential) increase in standard of living being turned against the very citizens whose productivity drove the increase in the standard of living in the first place. Even if Trump comes around to embrace this "not-thought-of-here" GOP tax plan, I don't currently believe legislation could pass either body before 30 April. This might change, however, if the rest of the Trump agenda continues to face sagging support, and he needs to breath new life and enthusiasm into his so-called "movement."

Only the House has a realistic chance of passing the BAT. Senate Republicans have a 52-48 edge but several GOP members are unlikely to vote for passage. For example, Lee (R, UT) spoke out publicly against a VAT-like tax. Perdue (R, GA) is the former CEO of Dollar General and understands the effect what a BAT could have on retailers and consumers. Cornyn (R, TX) is concerned about its effects on gasoline prices. He also is the #2 Republican in the Senate. Factors favoring House passage:
1) The House Republicans outnumber Democrats by 47. They could tolerate the defection of 23 and still win passage of a House bill 
2) House Leader Ryan has been a strong proponent of such a tax Factors against passage:
1) Though some economists argue a BAT may be "budget-neutral" overall, it may cause financial hardship for many large corporations that employ many workers (auto industry, electronics, Walmart, etc.). Expect heavy ad-campaigns from them against it.
2) House re-elections will be in 2018. Depending on the economy, Republicans who voted in favor of a BAT may be viewed unfavorably by voters as anti-consumer/pro-tariff. Furthermore, because it is unlikely to pass the Senate, Representatives in toss-up districts will be more likely to defect
3) Few Democrats would be willing to defect given the current acrimony over Trump http://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-tax-senate-idUSKBN15G50O
This will probably be done but time frame too short.

Stop!!!  - This appears to be a "fake" question. Q asked about a "border adjustment tax".  A "border adjustment tax" is not imposed at the border: it involves the treatment of import and export costs on corporate tax submissions. The more info section then gives examples of a "border tax" that are applied at the time of entry to products from specific countries or industries.   This confusion of two completely different concepts; a "border tax" (threatened by DT) and a "border adjustment tax" (advocated by PRyan and his tax reformation plan), needs further explanation.   However, given that a "border adjustment tax" requires new Congressional tax legislation that is impossible in the first hundred days means the forecast must be zero...  Although, one can certainly forecast that there will likely be judging issues on this Q, since the Q, by asking about "border adjustment taxes" then offering examples of "border taxes" seems to fail to understand the difference between two completely different ideas.
http://www.forbes.com/sites/beltway/2017/01/26/border-adjusted-taxes-and-a-big-border-tax-are-not-the-same-here-are-four-reasons-why/#95f67d750531 P. Ryan tax reform will wait until spring at the earliest (Congress now seems to be on Muskey time):
http://www.cnbc.com/2017/02/02/paul-ryan-we-cant-start-on-tax-reform-and-infrastructure-until-spring.html
